Package com.ibm.streams.management

Interface OperationListenerMXBean

public interface OperationListenerMXBean
OperationListenerMXBean provides access to messages generated while a bean operation is in progress.

An OperationListenerMXBean is created by calling createOperationListener on the bean to monitor. To monitor the status messages for an operation, the OperationListenerMXBean Id attribute value is passed as a parameter on the operation. Only a subset of operations support this parameter.

One of the following methods can be used to build the ObjectName for an OperationListenerMXBean.

ObjectNameBuilder.domainOperationListener(String, String)
ObjectNameBuilder.domainActiveServiceOperationListener(String, com.ibm.streams.management.domain.DomainServiceMXBean.Type, String, String, String)
ObjectNameBuilder.domainServiceOperationListener(String, com.ibm.streams.management.domain.DomainServiceMXBean.Type, String)
ObjectNameBuilder.instanceActiveServiceOperationListener(String, String, com.ibm.streams.management.instance.InstanceServiceMXBean.Type, String, String, String)
ObjectNameBuilder.instanceOperationListener(String, String, String)
ObjectNameBuilder.instanceServiceOperationListener(String, String, com.ibm.streams.management.instance.InstanceServiceMXBean.Type, String)
ObjectNameBuilder.jobOperationListener(String, String, java.math.BigInteger, String)
ObjectNameBuilder.operatorOperationListener(String, String, java.math.BigInteger, String, String)
ObjectNameBuilder.peOperationListener(String, String, java.math.BigInteger, String)
ObjectNameBuilder.resourceManagerOperationListener(String, String, String)
ObjectNameBuilder.resourceOperationListener(String, String, String)

An OperationListenerMXBean can be reused for multiple operations. The listener messages are cleared each time the listener is used for a new operation. The behavior is undefined if a single OperationListenerMXBean is used to monitor multiple operations concurrently. Multiple OperationListenerMXBean objects should be created in this case.

The unregister operation should be called after the listener is no longer needed to free the associated memory. If the listener is not unregistered and there is no activity on it for a period of time defined by JMX_INACTIVITY_TIMEOUT the listener is automatically unregistered. All associated operation listeners are also automatically unregistered when the monitored bean is unregistered.

Notifications:
The following notifications are supported on an OperationListenerMXBean.

Notifications.OPERATION_STATUS_COMPLETED
Notifications.OPERATION_STATUS_ERROR
Notifications.OPERATION_STATUS_INFORMATION
Notifications.OPERATION_STATUS_WARNING

Notification categories:
These categories can be used with notification filters to enable or disable all notifications for a category.
Notifications.OPERATION_NOTIFICATION

      static final String TYPE
      TYPE is used to identify this bean as an operation listener bean when building the bean's ObjectName.
      See Also:
      • Constant Field Values

  • Method Details

    • getId

      String getId()
      Returns the unique identifier for this listener. Use this value as a parameter on operations which support a listenerId parameter for monitoring the progress of the operation.
      Returns:
      the listener identifier.

    • getMessages

      List<OperationStatusMessage> getMessages()
      Returns the list of messages received for the most recently monitored operation. If the operation is in progress, this list contains all messages received by the time getMessages() was called.
      Returns:
      the list of messages received for an operation.

    • getMonitoredObject

      ObjectName getMonitoredObject()
      Returns the object name of the bean for which operations are monitored.
      Returns:
      the object name of the monitored bean.

    • unregister

      void unregister()
      Unregisters the operation listener which frees the memory associated with it. To avoid memory issues associated with a large number of allocated operation listeners, listeners should be unregistered when they are no longer needed. All listeners for a monitored bean are unregistered when the monitored bean is unregistered or after a period of inactivity defined by JMX_INACTIVITY_TIMEOUT.
